content:
Eight. Eight of them dead. Neighbors. People I've known my whole life.

I'm not sad. I'm furious. Is that wrong?
historicalContext: Eight colonial militiamen were killed at Lexington Green on April 19, 1775 - the first deaths of the American Revolution.

content:
Someone's screaming in the street. Grabbed my gun. Kissed Sarah. Told her I'd be home by morning.

The look on her face.
historicalContext: Paul Revere's midnight ride warned colonists that British troops were approaching. Militia members left their families in the middle of the night.

content:
They shot at us from behind trees. Behind walls. Everywhere. For twenty miles.

I've never run so much in my life. I've never been so scared.
historicalContext: British forces retreated from Concord under constant attack. They suffered 273 casualties on the march back to Boston.

content:
We ran out of powder. Had to run. But before that...

Three times they came up that hill. Three times.

My hands won't stop shaking.
historicalContext: At Bunker Hill (actually Breed's Hill), colonial militia repelled two British assaults before retreating when ammunition ran out.

content:
They picked me. Of all people.

I told them I wasn't good enough. They didn't listen.

I'm going to let everyone down. I can feel it.
historicalContext: Congress appointed George Washington Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army on June 15, 1775.

content:
Got the Virginian nominated. Needed someone from the South - can't have this be just a Massachusetts thing.

He looked terrified. Good. Means he understands.
historicalContext: John Adams strategically nominated George Washington to unite northern and southern colonies. Washington was from Virginia.

content:
Met the 'army' today. Farmers. Boys. Some of them don't have shoes.

They cheered when they saw me. Why?
historicalContext: Washington took command of the Continental Army on July 3, 1775. The forces were poorly equipped militia, not professional soldiers.

content:
Half of them leave tomorrow. Enlistments over. Happy new year.

I'm going to be commanding an army of ghosts.
historicalContext: Most Continental Army enlistments expired on December 31, 1775. Washington faced losing half his force.

content:
Read this pamphlet that's going around. 'Common Sense.' The man wrote what I've been thinking for years.

Why didn't I write it? Why couldn't I say it like that?
historicalContext: Thomas Paine's 'Common Sense' was published January 10, 1776. It sold 500,000 copies and openly argued for independence.

content:
Everyone's talking about this Paine fellow. 'These are the times that try men's souls.'

I'm jealous. Seventy years old and I'm jealous of a writer.
historicalContext: Benjamin Franklin, himself a famous writer, admired Paine's work. (The famous line is actually from Paine's later work 'The Crisis.')

content:
They're leaving. Boarding ships. It worked.

Eleven months. Eleven months watching them sit in Boston. And now they're going.

I can't feel my face. Is that relief?
historicalContext: British forces evacuated Boston on March 17, 1776 after Washington fortified Dorchester Heights with artillery.

content:
Ships. Leaving. I can see them from here.

I'm crying. The children are asking why. I don't have words.
historicalContext: Abigail Adams watched the British evacuation of Boston from nearby Braintree.

content:
Lee said the word today. In Congress. Out loud.

Some men looked like they might faint. I wanted to stand on the table and scream.
historicalContext: Richard Henry Lee introduced the resolution for independence on June 7, 1776.

content:
They want me to write it. Adams wouldn't. Franklin has gout.

Fine. I'll write the thing.

...how do you start something like this?
historicalContext: Jefferson was chosen to draft the Declaration of Independence on June 11, 1776.

content:
Everything is wrong. They came from behind. Hundreds gone.

I have to get everyone off this island. Tonight. Or there won't be anyone left.
historicalContext: The Battle of Long Island (August 27, 1776) was a devastating defeat. Washington faced losing his entire army.

content:
Nine thousand men. One night. Across the river.

Fog covered us. They didn't see. I don't know how. I don't know how.

I'm shaking.
historicalContext: Washington evacuated 9,000 troops from Brooklyn to Manhattan overnight. A providential fog concealed them at dawn.

content:
They hanged him this morning. Twenty-one. A schoolteacher.

His last words... I can't stop hearing them. 'One life to lose.'

He was twenty-one.
historicalContext: Nathan Hale was executed as a spy on September 22, 1776. He allegedly said 'I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.'

content:
Had them read Paine's words to the men tonight. 'Summer soldier.' 'Sunshine patriot.'

They needed to hear it. I needed to hear it.

It's so cold.
historicalContext: Washington had 'The American Crisis' read to troops before the Delaware crossing. The pamphlet began: 'These are the times that try men's souls.'

content:
Christmas. Crossing a river. In sleet. Men with no shoes leaving blood on the ice.

The password tonight is 'Victory or Death.' I meant it literally.
historicalContext: Washington crossed the Delaware on Christmas night 1776. Many soldiers lacked shoes and left bloody footprints.

content:
We won. A thousand prisoners. Maybe four of ours dead.

We actually won something.

I think I'm crying. Don't tell anyone.
historicalContext: The Battle of Trenton (December 26, 1776) was a decisive American victory. Nearly 1,000 Hessians were captured.

content:
Can't feel my hands. Marched all night. Hit them at dawn and it was over in an hour.

I can't believe we did that. I can't believe any of this.
historicalContext: Continental soldiers marched nine miles through a winter storm and achieved complete surprise at Trenton.

content:
Just got the news. They did it. They actually did it.

I was ready to give up. I'll admit it. I was ready.

I take it back. All of it.
historicalContext: News of Trenton reached Congress in Baltimore days after the battle. Morale had been at its lowest point.

content:
Snuck past them in the night. Hit them at dawn. Again.

Two in eight days. The men are looking at me different now.

Maybe we can actually do this.
historicalContext: The Battle of Princeton (January 3, 1777) was another surprise victory. Washington's army had been considered finished weeks before.

content:
They're officially rebels now. Traitors. Every one of them.

I gave them everything. EVERYTHING. And this is what they do.
historicalContext: King George III issued the Proclamation of Rebellion on August 23, 1775, declaring the colonies in open revolt.

content:
Read their 'declaration.' Every word of it.

Tyrant? TYRANT?

They'll learn what a tyrant really looks like.
historicalContext: News of the Declaration of Independence reached King George III in mid-August 1776.

content:
Wrote John again. Told him to remember the ladies. I was half joking.

Half.
historicalContext: Abigail Adams wrote to John: 'Remember the ladies, and be more generous and favorable to them than your ancestors.'

content:
Allen took the fort. Walked right in and took it.

'In the name of the Great Jehovah' - I love that man. Completely mad. But I love him.
historicalContext: Ethan Allen captured Fort Ticonderoga on May 10, 1775 with his Green Mountain Boys.

content:
Three thousand men. Gone. Captured. All our supplies. All our cannon.

I watched from across the river. Couldn't do anything.

This might be it.
historicalContext: Fort Washington fell on November 16, 1776. Nearly 3,000 Americans were captured - one of the worst defeats of the war.

content:
Down to maybe three thousand. Running. Always running.

Wrote my brother: 'The game is pretty near up.'

It's not. It can't be. But maybe it is.
historicalContext: By December 1776, Washington's army had shrunk from 20,000 to about 3,000. He wrote despairingly to his brother.
